HEADER.TITLE: The World Population Project
ABOUT.INTRO: Population.io aims to make demography – the study of human populations – accessible to a wider audience. We believe that demographic data can play an important role in understanding the social and economic developments of our time. Our hope is that people from all walks of life, in all ages and across all countries will explore a new perspective of their own life and find their own place in the world of today and tomorrow.
ABOUT.CREDITS_CORE: Population.io has been developed by Wolfgang Fengler, together with K.C. Samir and Benedikt Groß.
ABOUT.CREDITS_SUPPORTED: The project is a volunteer effort which has been supported by the World Bank Data Group and the International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis (IIASA). The team also appreciates the partnership with the United Nations Population Division, which is providing the estimates and projections, on which our model is based on (see methodology). And just has been possible with the generous volunteer contributions of (latest to oldest):
ABOUT.CREDITS_CONTRIBUTERS: Rafał Trójniak (backend/cloud computing), Andrew Whitby (algorithms and implementation in Python), Łukasz Caputa (consulting mobile apps), Tamás Krisztin (algorithms and implementation in Python), Joey Lee (maps, GIS and R to Python porting), 47 Nord (layouts and implementation α version) and Emi Suzuki (demographic data).
ABOUT.DISCLAIMER:
The interpolated values used in the application have been developed by the team of Population.io and were derived from different sets of estimates and projections published in the United Nations Population Division’s World Population Prospects, the 2012 Revision. They reflect the most up to date estimates for each country as well as for the world as a whole. There remain data quality issues, especially for developing countries. It is also important to note that, especially for the projection of life expectancy, the system is calculating the mid-points of probability functions (see section on methodology). Life expectancy, however, is determined by many factors and Population.io only highlights three of them: existing age, gender and country of birth/residence. Life expectancy will also be shaped by many future developments, some of which will be unforeseen.
Population.io does not take any responsibility for the accuracy of the data and will invest in upgrading the system as more data and the results of additional modelling become available.
METHODOLOGY.INTRO: Population.io uses official demographic data produced by the United Nations and published in the World Population Prospects (see data sources for details) most of which is available in annual or 5-year cycles. Population.io uses the past estimates for 1950-2010 and the medium population projection up to 2100 and interpolates the distribution daily for the World and for 200 countries (excluding few countries with small population size) and uses the UN’s estimates and projections of life tables for interpolating individual life expectancy by date and place of birth. For further information see our Methodology/Modeling page.
API.INTRO:
All of the data you see on population.io is from a restful API which is nicely documented with details of methods and data sources used here:
api.population.io
The source code behind this site and the API is also available at: github.com/worldpopulation and developers are welcome to build on both the application and API.
HOME.TEXT_BIG: What's my place in the world population? How long will I live?
HOME.TEXT_SMALL:
The Journey of your life in numbers and dates!
Please enter your date of birth, country of birth and sex at birth:
SUMMARY.INTRO: Do you think you belong to the young or old? You are the {{rankGlobal | number : 0}} person alive on the planet. This means that you are older than {{(rankGlobal/(worldPopulation/100) | number : 0)}}% of the world's population and older than {{calcCountryYoungerPercentageSimple()}}% of all people in {{profile.country}}.
MILESTONES.INTRO: What are the big milestones to expect in your life? Your next milestone is 17th Jan, 2021, then you’ll be 5th billionth person to be alive in the world.
BIRTHDAYS.INTRO: Did you know that you share a birthday with about {{sharedDay}} people around the world and that approximately {{sharedHour}} people were born in the same hour?
EXPECTANCY.INTRO: Imagine you lived today in a different country and with the life expectancy from a different time - how long could you expect to live?
EXPECTANCY.MAP_POINTER:
{{year}}
years of life left
in {{country}}

We estimate you will live
until age {{age}} years
{{date}}
DEATH.INTRO: We estimate that you will live until {{dodWorld}} if you were an average world citizen. Whereas in {{profile.country}} it would be until {{dodCountry}}.
DEATH.EXPECTANCY_TXT_WORLD:
You are expected to live
{{remainingLifeWorldInYears}} years as a citizen of the World
DEATH.EXPECTANCY_TXT_DIFFERENCE: Your life will be approximately {{soMuchToDo}} than the world's average for about {{differenceInUnits}}
DEATH.EXPECTANCY_TXT_COUNTRY:
You are expected to live
{{remainingLifeCountryInYears}} years as a citizen of {{profile.country}}
